items.title: Clean up README files

labels.name: merged
labels.description: ready for final test and close issue

items.body: Move README.md to .github folder and delete README.txt.

items.title: Installer doesn't create seamly2d folders
items.body:
The installer is supposed to create these seamly2d folders under the user's home directory.
This problem has been replicated on Linux and Windows. Hasn't been tested on MAC.

- seamly2d/
- seamly2d/layouts/
- seamly2d/measurements/
- seamly2d/measurements/individual/
- seamly2d/measurements/multisize/
- seamly2d/patterns/
- seamly2d/templates/

Most OS's will create these directories whenever a user is saving a pattern or measurement file, which is why this problem wasn't noticed immediately.

items.title: Seamly2d doesn't compile on Qt 5.13 and above.

labels.name: Qt
labels.description: Qt IDE issues and enhancements

items.body:
Since Qt 5.13 QSharedDataPtr class has some requirements like std::is_move_constructible and std::is_trivially_move_assignable among others, which are incompatible with forward declared class (FWDDCL). 
In particular all of the headers that define the Swap functions for QSharedDataPtr<FWDDCL> will fail to compile, unless the definitions are moved to cpp files, where the internal classes definition is visible.

items.title: "Point intersect arc and axis" tool bug
items.body:
In Ubuntu 18.04.4 LTS, using Seamly in both the 2018 & June 15 Appimage versions ![June2020appimageINFO](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/66974682/85625207-b041a900-b630-11ea-9319-889d57aa5631.png)

Forum post is here: https://forum.seamly.net/t/punkt-schneidet-kreisbogen-und-achse-issue-intersecting-arc-and-line/4213/10?u=pneumarian
When using the "Point intersect arc and axis" tool I have found the angle placement to be very erratically 180 off. It started when I was trying to make a line toward the Right on a twenty foot circumference circle, & both 0 (which should have worked,) & 180 insisted on pointing LEFT. So I made a compass rose with the labels on the outside of the circle in the direction which they should have been pointing. First in inches:
![CompassRose](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/66974682/85622420-6ce53b80-b62c-11ea-94cd-2e86c60c68ed.png)
& then in CM:
![MetricCompassRose](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/66974682/85622428-6f479580-b62c-11ea-9394-3feab0882268.png)
As you can see, some of the rays are pointing properly, some are mirrored, & some are just plain opposite. & they vary by the radius of the circle, as can be seen in comparing the 2ft & the 20cm versions. In none of the sizes I experimented with were all 8 radii in agreement, whether wrong or right.

The .val for the 2ft circumference circle is in the forum post linked above.

items.title: SeamlyMe.appimage doesn't open from Seamly2D.appimage

labels.name: merged
labels.description: ready for final test and close issue

items.body:
The appimage pipeline created in issue #220 works properly to create the Seamly2D.appimage and SeamlyMe.appimage.
A problem occurs when trying to open SeamlyMe.appimage from within Seamly2D.appimage using the Measurements dropdown menu. Nothing happens when selecting any option in the Measurements dropdown menu -- SeamlyMe.appimage does not open.
Running SeamlyMe.appimage by clicking on it from within a directory folder works fine.

items.title: proposed Windows build gives error about missing VCRUNTIME140_1.dll during install

labels.name: merged
labels.description: ready for final test and close issue

items.body:
Add VCRUNTIME140_1.dll for Visual Studio compatibility on Windows. Implicitly link to this dll by placing it in the same directory as seamly2d.exe.
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/578399/83916680-3a39d880-a73b-11ea-93ca-ff367c34bfd4.png)


Background on this issue:
- https://support.microsoft.com/en-us/help/2977003/the-latest-supported-visual-c-downloads 
- https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/cpp/windows/determining-which-dlls-to-redistribute?view=vs-2019 
- https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/cpp/build/linking-an-executable-to-a-dll?view=vs-2019
https://answers.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/forum/windows_10-update/vcruntime140dll/b1a15b0e-e389-41a3-bc49-f4fc85bac575

Apparently the 32-bit version of the dll will run on both 32- and 64-bit machines. Use the 64-bit only if the build is 64-bit, which I believe is not the case for Seamly2D at the moment.

Place file into the /dist/win source code directory. Update common.pri, etc. for .dll distribution

items.title: Create new CI/CD pipeline for all OS's

labels.name: merged
labels.description: ready for final test and close issue

items.body:
We currently use multiple CI/CD services for testing & building executables for three OS's. This has proven to be difficult to support.

Solution: Create a CI/CD pipeline to test & create Windows, MAC, and Linux binaries using Github's new Actions and Workflow features to reduce the number of outside accounts required, and simplify support. 

The build pipeline should create a weekly version for each OS from our develop branch, and also build new releases when appropriate.

The resulting artifacts (executable binaries) should be stored on our Github repo not with an outside service provider.

items.title: Create tags for development branch builds, based on date

labels.name: merged
labels.description: ready for final test and close issue

items.body:
Begin incremental Test builds

1. Create a `TestBuild` tag locally
2. Create a release record for the  `TestBuild` tag
3. To create the next incremental test build:
   a. Fetch current develop branch
   b. Update the `TestBuild` tag (using `git tag -f TestBuild`) in the local repository to point to the commit the nightly build was run from
   b. Push the updated `nightly` tag to the GitHub repo using `git push --tags -f`
   c. Delete all old Test assets and upload any new assets

items.title: Seamly crashes after moving pointer in History dialog
items.body:
Hello,
I noticed an anomaly which is very unpleasant and which makes the program crash but which can be easily corrected.
When we move the pointer in the history to add an object that we forgot, the object is added but the pointer does not advance.
Thus, if we now add a second object that uses the first, the software refuses the creation or freezes if we insist.
It would be enough to advance the pointer at each addition to solve the problem.
I hope you find my contribution useful.

items.title: Fix Linux xmlpatterns library name in README

labels.name: merged
labels.description: ready for final test and close issue

items.body:
The xmlpatterns library name is incorrect, should be libqt5xmlpatterns5-dev

With Linux distributions, the xmlpatterns file is sometimes absent from the Qt installation so users need to install it separately.
